answers.author: [Unknown]
answers.text:
Hello Nickie,    
I found these resources that might help answer your question.   
The Knowledge Network blog “In the Know” posted about Compressed Natural Gas and made reference to multiple cities who were committed to making the change.   http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/blogs/blogpost/562/Compressed_Natural_Gas_A_Better_Fuel_Alternativehttp://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/groups/kn/Group/1149/Energy_Efficiency_and_Renewable_Energy
Here is the link to our Knowledge Network group, "Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy."  This may be a group you would have interest in joining.     
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/groups/kn/Group/1149/Energy_Efficiency_and_Renewable_Energy 
The City of Clearwater in the state of Florida was an example of a case study that examined the transformation to CNG and their 'greener' city initiative.   
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302735/Compressed_Natural_Gas_Filling_StationThe 
The Knowledge Network topic "Alternative Fleet Vehicles" might have more information for you in regards to CNG fleets.     
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/9/Alternative_Fleet_Vehicles 
I hope this helps to answer your question! Let us know if we can help you find any additional resources.     
Hilary Badger   
Knowledge Network, Intern   
ICMA

answers.author: Pamela Muse
answers.text:
Nickie – I hope the following is helpful:
Temple, Texas to Build CNG Station and Convert Solid Waste Fleet to Natural Gas
http://www.government-fleet.com/channel/fuel-management/news/story/2013/05/temple-texas-to-build-cng-station-and-convert-solid-waste-fleet-to-natural-gas.aspx 
FL Cities convert to CNG: A third public station is set to open near the Port of Tampa by April of this year. http://www.83degreesmedia.com/features/natgas032613.aspx
The City of Trussville, Trussville Utilities, and McCullough Oil Co. marked the official opening of a new compressed natural gas (CNG) fueling station - http://www.greenfleetmagazine.com/news/51470/new-cng-fueling-station-opened-in-trussville-ala 
The City of Lafayette, La., is building a new compressed natural gas (CNG) fueling station. The station is inside the Lafayette Consolidated Government’s (LCG’s) public works department complex and will be used to fuel City-owned fleet vehicles and provide fueling to area businesses and individuals. - http://www.greenfleetmagazine.com/news/51404/cng-station-in-the-works-for-city-of-lafayette 
Dublin, OH
http://dublinohiousa.gov/city-of-dublin-compressed-natural-gas-cng-fueling-station/ 
Business Case for Compressed Natural Gas in Municipal Fleets
http://www.afdc.energy.gov/pdfs/47919.pdf 
Pam
Pamela Muse
Western Regional Director
Alliance for Innovation

pmuse@transformgov.org

answers.author: Jared Cobb
answers.text:
Nickie, CNG is expensive, however, it's an excellent alternative in the midwest. Gas shipped from Oklahoma is much cheaper than in other areas of the country. As Hilary and Pam suggested, Clearwater Gas successfully implemented a program and built a station. One way they spread the costs of infrastructure was by offering the service to the public. http://www.clearwatergas.com/

answers.author: Greg Reger
answers.text:
The City of Hamilton, OH currently has 4 CNG vehicles and 4 quasi-fast-fill pumps, and is completing the design of a CNG fueling station. Initially, it'll just be for our fleet (which we're looking into converting to CNG), but we aim to make it a public station. It'll cost around $1.3-1.5 million, and we received a CMAQ grant to cover $700,000 of the costs. We may also create a PPP moving forward.
Note that there are basically two types of CNG stations: slow-fill (which fill up vehicles overnight and is a cheaper option) and fast-fill (more comparable to your standard gas station, in terms of the time it takes to fill up a vehicle).  Hamilton's CNG station will be fast-fill; we don't want to discourage people from using it because it takes too long to fill up.
From everything I've read, CNG is a great option for refuse trucks, as they use so much fuel and return to a centralized location; I've seen simple paybacks of <3 years. It can make sense for other fleet vehicles, as they also return to a centralized location to refuel, but that depends on fuel price differentials, vehicle lifecycles, MPG, annual fuel usage, incremental cost of CNG systems, and other factors. Each vehicle will differ in terms of economic feasibility.
Although Hamilton is a municipal utility, we purchase gas from Atmos Energy (who looks to be Olathe's supplier), and they have been very supportive of this project. I'd suggest reaching out to them moving forward, as this is essentially a new market for them.
In terms of resources, the Business Case for Compressed Natural Gas in Municipal Fleets (see Pam's response) is useful, as is The Compelling Case For NGVs in Public and Private Fleets (see attached). For an economic analysis, and what the Business Case for CNG describes, you could use the DOE's Clean Cities VICE model (http://www1.eere.energy.gov/cleancities/news_detail.html?news_id=17674). Clean Cities KC (http://www.kcenergy.org/kccleancities.aspx) may also be a good resource for available grants & as a knowledge base. 
Feel free to contact me if you have any other questions. As a native of Overland Park, I'm always interested in seeing progressive initiatives take place in and around my hometown!

Feel free to contact me if you have any other questions. As a native of Overland Park, I'm always interested in seeing progressive initiatives take place in and around my hometown!

answers.author: Rayford Harris
answers.text:
The City of Richmond, Department of Public Works  (DPW) purchased 25 CNG refuse trucks and the Department of Public Utilities (DPU -Gas Utility Department) built a time- fill CNG in 2011.  The station is dedicated to fueling the refuse trucks. Since it went into service in March 2011 we have had excellent operating results, no equipment downtime while saving about $200K per year using natural gas versus diesel. The refuse employees prefer CNG trucks because they are so clean burning, operate very quietly, and the trucks fill overnight at the yard and ready to roll in the morning (no need to waste time going to a fueling station)
We have our own fueling station and we also use other fueling stations.  DPU owns and operates the refuse CNG station for the refuse trucks. The City also purchases CNG from an investor owned station. 
In September 2012, Clean Energy opened a public access CNG station in Richmond. The station is located about a mile from our Department of Public Utilities Operations Center.  Instead of building a 2nd CNG fueling facility, we decided to use the Clean Energy station for all new (non refuse truck) CNG vehicles.  Our local municipally owned transit company (GRTC) recently signed a contract with Trillium CNG to build their station which will eventually fuel over 200 CNG buses. Until it is completed in January 2014 GRTC, will use the Clean Energy station too.  Other agencies within the City are investigating or in the process of purchasing CNG vehicles to replace gasoline or diesel trucks. So far, the Clean Energy Station has been operating great. Our current price per GGE is approximately $1.60.
Please feel free to call Michael Kearns in DPU Energy Services at 804-646-5215 or Michael.Kearns@Richmondgov.com if you have any additional questions.

answers.author: James Twombly
answers.text:
The City of Tulsa opened a public CNG station this past fall, see http://www.krmg.com/news/news/local/city-tulsa-debuts-new-cng-fueling-station/nR5mz/.  As the article says the local transit authority has converted to CNG and built their own fueling station.  We awarded a new contract for solid waste pick up that required the hauler to use an all CNG fleet.  They also built their own fueling station.  The local gas company, Oklahoma Natural Gas, has several stations within the metro area.  Our public station was built in part with a federal clean air grant and cost in the neighborhood of the costs seen above.  We are continuing to convert current fleet to CNG and buying bi-fuel trucks as we replace aging stock.  Our Equipment Management Director Brent Jones can be reached at 918-596-9821 or bjones@cityoftulsa.org.

Our Equipment Management Director Brent Jones can be reached at 918-596-9821 or bjones@cityoftulsa.org.

answers.author: Jill Silverboard
answers.text:
The City of Clearwater opened a public (quick-fill) CNG station in October 2011.  As an existing natural gas utility, opening our own CNG station made economic sense.  We have purchased 7 CNG solid waste vehicles to date with an average payback of 2 years.  Each new solid waste vehicle purchased is CNG. The station is open to the public and we have several private utility with CNG fleets using the facility.  In addition to our solid waste vehicles, we are purchasing bi-fuel vehicles for other departments and operations.  Please contact Brian Langille, Gas Operations Manager at 727-562-4900 x7406 for additional information.


The City of Clearwater opened a public (quick-fill) CNG station in October 2011.  As an existing natural gas utility, opening our own CNG station made economic sense. The station is open to the public and we have several private utility with CNG fleets using the facility.  In addition to our solid waste vehicles, we are purchasing bi-fuel vehicles for other departments and operations.  Please contact Brian Langille, Gas Operations Manager at 727-562-4900 x7406 for additional information.

answers.author: Gary Holland
answers.text:
After managing a CNG fleet vehicle demonstration many years ago, I have continued to monitor progress with the CNG concept. My demonstration project included refuse collection trucks, police patrol cars, and regular passenger cars. A quick-fill fueling system was used. The results were excellent, but recent improvements in CNG conversion kits and fueling systems makes CNG even more attractive.
One important factor to incorporate into the financial analysis is the extended life of vehicle engines and reduced maintenance costs realized with CNG. Another consideration is the concern by staff for safety. CNG has been proven safer than gasoline or propane.
Regarding the cost of a refueling system, shared use can be pursued between city, county, and school district operators of fleet vehicles if political and location issues can be resolved. As mentioned by others, some local governments make their refueling systems available to the general public. Also, some private firms specializing in CNG fueling systems/conversions will install and operate fueling systems to "sell" natural gas to the jurisdiction, thus allowing the jurisdiction to avoid the capital investment (Tulsa Gas Technologies offers this option - Tom Sewell, 918-665-2641)

The results were excellent, but recent improvements in CNG conversion kits and fueling systems makes CNG even more attractive.

One important factor to incorporate into the financial analysis is the extended life of vehicle engines and reduced maintenance costs realized with CNG. Another consideration is the concern by staff for safety. CNG has been proven safer than gasoline or propane.

Regarding the cost of a refueling system, shared use can be pursued between city, county, and school district operators of fleet vehicles if political and location issues can be resolved. As mentioned by others, some local governments make their refueling systems available to the general public. Also, some private firms specializing in CNG fueling systems/conversions will install and operate fueling systems to "sell" natural gas to the jurisdiction, thus allowing the jurisdiction to avoid the capital investment (Tulsa Gas Technologies offers this option - Tom Sewell, 918-665-2641)

answers.author: Michael Smith
answers.text:
The City of Oklahoma City has converted a significant portion of its fleet to CNG and has constructed both slow and fast fill CNG sites at our Central Maintenance Facility.  Our solid waste division currently has 18 CNG vehicles in service, 5 more in the final acceptance process, and six more scheduled to be purchased next fiscal year.  With the conversion of the solid waste fleet, we are also constructing a CNG station at the solid waste facilities.  The CNG station will be set up for public & city fleet access.  The fleet access will be located in the secure area with slow fill nozzels at all of the designated park spots along with a central fast fill island.  The public will be able to fast fill their CNG vehicles at a non-attended roadside station outside of the secured area
If you have additional questions please contact:
Solid Waste, Fleet Services Coordinator
Kenneth Mitchell
405.297.3576
kenneth.mitchell@okc.gov
The City of Oklahoma City, Fleet Services Coordinator
Richard Stehr
405.297.2469
richard.stehr@okc.gov

answers.author: Jeffry Swertfeger
answers.text:
Nickie,
We work with a host of different companies, municipalities, and fleet owners on station design, construction, and ownership. TruStar Energy was formed from a group of refuse industry professionals who have decades of experience and understand your market segment very well. We are currently working with Veolia, Advanced Disposal, Vogel Disposal, Suburban, Dick's Sanitation, Ace Solid Waste, etc. We offer stations that range in price and performance [all depending on the fueling needs you're looking for]. Please go to http://www.trustarenergy.com and input your own fleet's performance needs into our cost calculator for a quick estimate of your potential fuel savings. We also offer 'no-cost fuel station options - that work for several of our customers as well. Know that you have options. If you would like to know more, don't hesitate to call:
Jeff Swertfeger
Director of Marketing
TruStar Energy
813-957-1846
jswertfeger@trustarenergy.com

author: Nickie Lee
text: We are considering purchasing CNG-fueled solid waste trucks and if that's successful, converting more of our fleet to CNG. Since we do not have adequte CNG fueling stations nearby we are considering building our own. Has anyone else converted to a CNG fleet, and how has your experience been? Do you have your own fueling station or do you use someone else's? Any feedback is appreciated!
title: CNG Fleets and Fueling Stations
